Award.AwardTitle: Iterative Model Building (IMB): A Program for Training Quality Teachers and Measuring Teacher Quality

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to improve professional development programs for pre-service teachers (PSTs) as a way to improve student learning in mathematics and science. PSTs engage in a series of teaching cycles beginning by working with pairs of elementary school students to create models of their mathematics and science knowledge (teaching experiments). The PSTs then engage in lesson study groups to develop, teach, and analyze a whole class lesson. The cycle is completed by reexamining students' knowledge in teaching experiments with pairs of students. These teaching cycles are called Iterative Model Building (IMB). Six specific research questions are investigated.

The six research questions are: 1.) Do PSTs exhibit growth in their understanding of how students reason; 2.) Do PSTs exhibit growth in their ability to design appropriate whole class lessons and activities based on where students are; 3.) Do PSTs exhibit growth in their ability to plan instruction as part of a collaborative research community; 4.) How do PSTs' beliefs and knowledge about the nature of math and science mature throughout the program; 5.) Are there significant differences between teacher practices in classrooms taught by IMB PSTs compared to other PSTs; 6.) What do teacher quality measures tell us about our current program and the proposed approach?

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Iterative Model Building (IMB) project was a three-phase study focused on improving teacher quality through the implementation of an intensive math and science field experience approach. In Phase One, elementary preservice teachers took part in either an experimental IMB field experience or a control field experience. For Phase Two, preservice teachers from Phase One were followed into student teaching to gather data regarding teaching quality. In Phase Three, these same preservice teachers were followed into their first year as classroom teachers to gather additional data about their teaching practice.

Results suggest that teaching aspects fostered by the IMB approach had a positive effect that was apparent during student teaching. We found evidence that lesson planning and enactment by IMB participants exhibited teaching aspects fostered during the field experience. In particular, the IMB participants’ written lesson plans showed strength in the objectives and adaptations sections as well as the launch and investigate sections. As far as the enactment of the lessons, IMB participants showed strength in aspects of lesson design and classroom culture. We found evidence that IMB participants rated higher than control participants for written lesson plans and lesson observation. Based on observations, IMB participants were rated higher in several aspects of their teaching indicating they were better equipped to engage in student-centered teaching, make connections, and foster collaboration among students. We found evidence suggesting that the teaching of control group participants tended to be more traditional, teacher-centered, and had few connections to real life situations.

We developed several products that are used to implement the IMB approach. The products include a Field Experience Manual for students and a Field Experience Manual for instructors. These manuals outline the components of the IMB project and describe in detail the intricacies of the program, with the intention of helping others replicate the process. Additionally, we developed several assessments and manuals that provide guidelines for administering these assessments. One is a set of video-based assessments of preservice teachers’ attention to students’ mathematical and scientific reasoning that we call the Prediction Assessments. Another assessment was designed to measure preservice teachers’ growth in ten scales of beliefs, called the Confidence, Commitment, Collaboration, and Student thinking in Mathematics and Science (CCCSMS) beliefs scales. We also developed a graduate level seminar that graduate students in mathematics and science education can take prior to having an assistantship supervising the IMB field experience. The seminar has been institutionalized and is offered every other year. We also maintain a video library. The video library is password protected and houses hundreds of videos related to the project. The video library is used with the field experience course, but is also intended for educators as a source for video cases. The library has multiple levels of access and restrictions, based on the user. At present, several videos are available for the public as a component of this library by visiting, imbvideo.org.
